abstract.text: A type that identifies activity summary objects.

inlineContent.text: Use the activity summary type to request permission to read
objects from the HealthKit store. To create an activity summary type, use the
Although you can request permission to read
objects, you can’t request permission to share them. For more information, see
class is a concrete subclass of the
class. Like many HealthKit classes, activity summary types aren’t extensible and you shouldn’t subclass them.
Any workouts that you save to the HealthKit store may affect that day’s summary. For more information, see
To query for activity summary objects, use an
. You can also create your own
objects (for example, to display in an

abstract.text: Access and share health and fitness data while maintaining the user’s privacy and control.
An object that contains the move, exercise, and stand data for a given day.
A query for reading activity summary objects from the HealthKit store.
A type that identifies activity summary objects.
A type that identifies samples that contain audiogram data.
A type that identifies samples that contain a value from a small set of possible values.
A type that represents data that doesn’t typically change over time.
A type that identifies samples that contain clinical record data.
A type that identifies samples that group multiple subsamples.
A type that identifies samples containing electrocardiogram data.
Requests permission to save and read the specified data types.
An abstract superclass with subclasses that identify a specific type of data for the HealthKit store.
Returns the shared activity summary type.
A type that identifies samples that store numerical values.
An abstract superclass for all classes that identify a specific type of sample when working with the HealthKit store.
A type that indicates the data stored in a series sample.
A type that identifies samples that store information about a workout.
A view that uses the Move, Exercise, and Stand activity rings to display data from a HealthKit activity summary object.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
